message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: RT to Win! Predicting Message Propagation in Twitter
Paper Abstract: Twitter is a very popular way for people to share information on a bewildering multitude of topics. Tweets are propagated using a variety of channels: by following users or lists, by searching or by retweeting. Of these vectors, retweeting is arguably the most effective, as it can potentially reach the most people, given its viral nature. A key task is predicting if a tweet will be retweeted, and solving this problem furthers our understanding of message propagation within large user communities. We carry out a human experiment on the task of deciding whether a tweet will be retweeted which shows that the task is possible, as human performance levels are much above chance. Using a machine learning approach based on the passive-aggressive algorithm, we are able to automatically predict retweets as well as humans. Analyzing the learned model, we find that performance is dominated by social features, but that tweet features add a substantial boost.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "Machine learning." Here are the key findings:

## Overview
Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Applications
ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Learning Paradigms
Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms, supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Historical Development
The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Recent Advances
Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.(no content)By 2016 AlphaGo obtained victory against top human players using reinforcement learning techniques.

I've found search results for "Information propagation networks." Here's an overview of the key topics covered:

## Related Network Concepts

The search results cover several interconnected areas related to how information moves through networks:

**Propagation Mechanisms:**
- Belief propagation, also known as sum–product message passing, is a message-passing algorithm for performing inference on graphical models, such as Bayesian networks and Markov random fields.
- Label propagation is a semi-supervised algorithm in machine learning that assigns labels to previously unlabeled data points.

**Network Analysis:**
- Network science is an academic field which studies complex networks such as telecommunication networks, computer networks, biological networks, cognitive and semantic networks, and social networks, considering distinct elements or actors represented by nodes (or vertices) and the connections between the elements or actors as links (or edges).
- Centrality measures are essential when a network analysis has to answer questions such as: "Which nodes in the network should be targeted to ensure that a message or information spreads to all or most nodes in the network?"

**Physical Propagation:**
- Propagation graphs are a mathematical modelling method for radio propagation channels. A propagation graph is a signal flow graph in which vertices represent transmitters, receivers or scatterers.

These results show how information and signals propagate through various types of networks, from computational and social systems to physical communication channels.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the passive-aggressive algorithm:

The passive-aggressive algorithm is a machine learning algorithm used in online learning and classification tasks. It is mentioned alongside other algorithms like Perceptron and Confidence Weighted in multi-classification and regression contexts.

The passive-aggressive regressor is available as part of scikit-learn's out-of-core implementations for regression. In computer science, online machine learning is a method in which data becomes available in a sequential order and is used to update the best predictor for future data at each step, and the passive-aggressive algorithm is one such online learning approach.

The algorithm fits within the broader framework of online convex optimization, which is used in machine learning scenarios where it's computationally impractical to train on an entire dataset at once, or where the algorithm needs to dynamically adapt to new patterns in the data.

The search results show the passive-aggressive algorithm being referenced in frameworks like Jubatus (an open-source online machine learning platform) and scikit-learn (a popular Python machine learning library), indicating it's a practical tool used in modern machine learning applications.

Links: [{"title":"Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter"},{"title":"Twitter, Inc. - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twitter,_Inc."},{"title":"X (social network)","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X_(social_network)"},{"title":"Bluesky - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bluesky"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"Mastodon (social network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mastodon_(social_network)"},{"title":"List of Twitter features - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Twitter_features"},{"title":"History of Twitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Twitter"},{"title":"Social graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_graph"},{"title":"Truth Social - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth_Social"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Twitter:

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Core Features

Users could share concise text messages, images, and videos through "tweets" and engage with other users' content via likes or "retweets".(no content)Twitter set the trend for "real-time" services, wherein users can broadcast to the world what they are doing, or what is on their minds within a 140-character limit.

## History

Twitter's origins lie in a "daylong brainstorming session" held by board members of the podcasting company Odeo. Jack Dorsey, then an undergraduate student at New York University, introduced the idea of an individual using an SMS service to communicate with a small group.(no content)Work on the project started in February 2006. Dorsey published the first Twitter message on March 21, 2006, at 12:50 p.m. PST (UTC−08:00): "just setting up my twttr".

## Recent Changes

Twitter was rebranded as X in 2023.(no content)Following Musk's takeover, Twitter was criticized for an increase in hate speech, systemic prioritization of right-wing content and the removal of the feature to report tweets for spreading misinformation. His acquisition of the company has been characterized by large-scale policy changes, mass layoffs and resignations, and a dramatic shift in the company's work culture.

Users could share concise text messages, images, and videos through "tweets" and engage with other users' content via likes or "retweets".(no content)Twitter set the trend for "real-time" services, wherein users can broadcast to the world what they are doing, or what is on their minds within a 140-character limit.

## History

Twitter's origins lie in a "daylong brainstorming session" held by board members of the podcasting company Odeo. Jack Dorsey, then an undergraduate student at New York University, introduced the idea of an individual using an SMS service to communicate with a small group.(no content)Work on the project started in February 2006. Dorsey published the first Twitter message on March 21, 2006, at 12:50 p.m. PST (UTC−08:00): "just setting up my twttr".

## Recent Changes

Twitter was rebranded as X in 2023.(no content)Following Musk's takeover, Twitter was criticized for an increase in hate speech, systemic prioritization of right-wing content and the removal of the feature to report tweets for spreading misinformation. His acquisition of the company has been characterized by large-scale policy changes, mass layoffs and resignations, and a dramatic shift in the company's work culture.

## Search Results for "Retweet Social Media"

Here's what I found about retweets on social media:

### What is a Retweet?

A retweet (officially called a repost since July 2023) is the mechanism in social media that allows users to repost the content of another user's post with an indication that the source of the post is another user.

### History of Retweets

Twitter began rolling out the ability to 'retweet' a tweet in November 2009. Prior to this, people would write "RT @username" before quoting the original tweet.(no content)The "retweet" phenomenon began informally on Twitter in March 2007, when an informal protocol slowly developed among Twitter users.

### How Retweets Work

Users can interact with tweets by 'retweeting' (reblogging), liking, quoting the tweet, or replying to it.(no content)To repost a message from another Twitter user and share it with one's own followers, a user can click the retweet button within the tweet.

### Reblogging on Other Platforms

Tumblr built reblogging into their social network for re-sharing posts within the network, and similar features ("Retweet" on Twitter, "Share" on Facebook) then followed.

### Current Terminology

Following the acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk in October 2022, and rebranding of the site as "X" in July 2023, all references to "retweet" were changed to "repost". However, the terms "tweet" and "retweet" are still more popular when referring to posts on X.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "RT to Win! Predicting Message Propagation in Twitter". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution**
- The paper proposes a novel machine learning approach using the passive-aggressive algorithm to predict message propagation on Twitter
- It includes human experiments and model analysis to understand what features matter most

**Triples Extracted** (5 total):

1. **Machine learning** (method, uses) - The paper applies ML techniques to predict retweeting behavior
2. **Online machine learning** (method, proposes) - The paper proposes the passive-aggressive algorithm, an online ML approach for real-time prediction
3. **Twitter** (tool, uses) - The social network platform where message propagation is studied
4. **Tweet (social media)** (concept, uses) - The core content objects whose propagation patterns are analyzed
5. **Network science** (concept, uses) - The paper studies message propagation through social networks

**Validation Result**: ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The triples_output.json file has been properly formatted with all required fields (name, entity_type, relation, wikipedia_url, and relevance) and successfully validated against the requirements.
